docs.lead_paragraph: We have a letter from Fort Riley dated on the 5th inst. We make the following extract: "Everything here is now moving on quietly and well, under the superintendence of the able gentlemen who have charge of the Government works, and every one about the fort is in fine health.

headline.main: LONG ISLAND.; Mortallty in Brooklyn. The Sunday Ordinancein Brooklyn--Summary Punishment of a Boy. A Native African's Lectures on Africa. Reformed Dutch Church Kings Courts Hospital. Fire in Brooklyn. Mallcious Boys. Foundling.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health Officer reports 103 deaths as having occurred on the City of Brooklyn during the week ending the 22d inst., from the following: Diseases--Appoplexy, bronchitis, cancer of the womb, casualty, congestion of the brain, do lungs, convulsions, puerperal, cynbia, ?? tremens, dropsy in the abdomen, do heart, dysentery, maltormation, premature birth, sprue, ulcers of intestines--one each Group, debility, dropsy, do, chest, do, head,

headline.main: QUARANTINE.; PEOPLE WHO LIVE IN GLASS HOUSES, &c. New-York Vessels Quarantined at Baltimore. YELLOW FEVER CASE.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD, while the proceedings of the Board of Health were still secret, had written to the Baltimoreans gratifying assurances of his sympathy with them in the greiveous afection imposed by the order that their vessels should be examined at Quarantine, and detained if any aickness be found or board.

headline.main: Quarantine--His Honer's Personal Settlements--A Letter to Baltimore.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD yesterday sent the following delicate communication to Mayor HINKS, of Baltimore: MAYOR'S OFFICE, NEW-YORK, Sept. 21, 1855. MY DEAR SIR: Our Board of Health resolved yesterday to continue the examination of vessels from Baltimore until the 1st of November.
docs.abstract: Letter to the Mayor of Baltimore on the quarantine
